subNodes.conversationText: root
As the young witch approached the house, <he/she> heard what sounded like several voices speaking indoors, but <he/she> couldn't make out any words.
<FirstName> hesitated. <He/She> didn't like the idea of walking in uninvited.
But maybe the hunter who killed Nnenne lived here, though, or was one of the people inside.
The young witch knocked on the door.
Even so, <he/she> slipped away.
The young witch knocked on the door.
"It's him! It's got to be him!" said someone inside.
[Continue.]
"Make yourself useful, Blauvelt. Open the door," said another.
[Continue.]
A pudgy man with an unprepossessing face and garish clothes opened the door. He cleared his throat and looked <FirstName> up and down.
[Continue.]
"It's not him."
[Continue.]
"Well? Who is it then?"
[Continue.]

Knott had become a normal gourd again. He rested at the young witch's feet.

"A -- vegetable peddler. A poor farmer, perhaps," said the man named Blauvelt, seeing the gourd.
[Continue.]
"Nonsense! Not around here," cried another voice.
[Continue.]
Pharaoh, who had been observing from a nearby branch, alighted on the young witch's shoulder. Blauvelt's eyes went wide.
[Continue.]
"Ah! It's a witch! <He/She> has a crow and everything."
"Indeed. Am I late?" Faking an invitation seldom went wrong for <FirstName>.
"It's a witch? Better let <him/her> in. The last thing I need is another pox. My last one just cleared up."
[Continue.]
"You've slept with half the university. What's another pox?"
[Continue.]
"Half the university -- Is that what they say? I've slept with a good deal more than half."
[Continue.]
"Good deal for you, bad deal for them."
[Continue.]
"Not nice, love. Blauvelt, bring the witch inside. The more the merrier, the less the -- more morose. Perhaps <he/she>'s seen Nefril."
[Continue.]

Before <FirstName> could make any objections, <he/she> was ushered into the midst of a dozen people sitting at a table. The air was thick with smoke. Drained cups and empty plates were strewn about. The din quieted as <FirstName> took a seat.
[Continue.]
There were a few young men and women wearing academic regalia -- university students, <he/she> supposed.
[Continue.]

But there were other folk whose looks made them less easy to identify. Not students, certainly -- they were too old for that, and their soiled, plain clothes suggested hard days and nights on unkind roads.
[Continue.]
And then there was the person who had opened the door -- "Blauvelt, <Madame/Sir>," he said, bowing -- "And this here -- our kind host -- is Beltwane, the gentleman hunter!"
[Continue.]

A portly, sturdy man with a kind, weather-worn face smiled a little uncertainly at <FirstName> from across the table. He wore a foppish hat with a blood-red feather in it, but the rest of his garb -- dun, gray, and olive -- was more appropriate to his profession.
Could this man be Nnenne's killer?
<FirstName> would watch him carefully.
That this man could be Nnenne's killer seemed preposterous.
Still, <FirstName> resolved to watch him carefully.
[Continue.]
"So, witch, perhaps you've seen him," said the student who had been talking before; he'd introduced himself as Cladde.
"Perhaps I have. But who do you mean?"
"My dear friend Wencel, brother to Stuyvan --"
[Continue.]
"I'm looking for someone myself."
"Oh? Well, we've got almost every soul worth in these damn woods right here -- except our missing friend, of course."
The young witch surveyed the table and gave Cladde an unimpressed look.
<He/She> frowned as <he/she> studied Beltwane and said nothing.
"Is one of you a murderer?"
Some of the students laughed giddily, but the other folk gave odd, flat smiles and crossed their arms. Beltwane looked uneasy but said nothing.
[Continue.]

But now the novelty of the young witch's entrance had worn off, and people returned to their side conversations as Cladde turned to <him/her>.

"Not all of them are as frank and open as I -- I, who am clean of this sin but guilty of five hundred others. But you might learn something about this murderer of yours if you ask around. Meanwhile, I hope you don't mind if I ask you about our missing friend."
The hunter seemed suspicious. So, too, did his friends.
<FirstName> would watch him carefully.
[Continue.]
"So, witch, perhaps you've seen him," said the student who had been talking before; he'd introduced himself as Cladde.
"That's right," said <FirstName> haughtily.
"It's a witch? Better let <him/her> in. The last thing I need is another pox. My last one just cleared up."
"Pardon me. I'm looking for information."
Blauvelt hemmed and hawed and began to make an excuse, but he was interrupted.
[Continue.]
"It's a witch? Better let <him/her> in. The last thing I need is another pox. My last one just cleared up."
<He/She> slipped away.
<FirstName> returned to the door. From the sound of it, the party hadn't ended.
The young witch knocked on the door.
<He/She> slipped away.
